header: (FR) Deciding when to start your public pensions

key-takeaways.heading: (FR) Key takeaways
key-takeaways.highest-monthly-amount: (FR) The highest monthly amount you can start collecting from your public pensions is at age 70.
key-takeaways.start-collecting: (FR) You can start collecting your Canada Pension Plan (CPP) retirement pension as early as age 60 with permanent reduction. You can start receiving your Old Age Security (OAS) pension as early as age 65.
key-takeaways.payment-increase: (FR) Your monthly payment will increase every month you delay, up to age 70.
key-takeaways.no-benefit: (FR) There's no benefit to wait after age 70 to start collecting both pensions.
key-takeaways.people-who-qualify: (FR) People who qualify for the Guaranteed Income Supplement (GIS) should not wait to apply past age 65.
key-takeaways.if-you-qualify: (FR) If you qualify for the Old Age Security (OAS) pension and have low income, you may also get the GIS. You cannot receive the GIS if you are delaying your OAS pension. You may also consider taking your Canada Pension Plan (CPP) retirement pension early.
key-takeaways.more-than-double: (FR) You could more than double your monthly CPP amount if you delay your retirement pension from age 60 to 70.
key-takeaways.pensions-adjusted: (FR) Your pensions will be adjusted for inflation in the future.
key-takeaways.planning-retirement: (FR) When planning your retirement, you should consider a few factors: your health, your lifestyle, your plans in retirement, and your finances.
key-takeaways.common-law: (FR) If you're part of a couple, you should probably make these decisions with your spouse or common-law partner.

overview.heading: (FR) Overview
overview.p1: (FR) The Old Age Security (OAS) pension and Canada Pension Plan (CPP) retirement pensions replace a part of your income in retirement. They contribute to a safe base that can build a secure and comfortable retirement. If you've worked or lived in Quebec, you may qualify for the Québec Pension Plan (QPP) retirement pension instead of the CPP. These programs are very similar, but not the same.
overview.p2: (FR) To learn more, visit the <a1>QPP website</a1>.
overview.p3: (FR) The OAS pension and CPP retirement pension provide flexibility for when to start collecting. This decision will permanently set your pension amount, which is payable for life. Your public pensions are always increasing to reflect inflation.
overview.p4: (FR) The information below aims to help you decide at what age to start your public pensions.

old-age-security.heading: (FR) Old Age Security (OAS) Pension
old-age-security.content-one: (FR) You can start collecting your Old Age Security (OAS) pension as early as age 65. Each month you delay increases that amount by 0.6%. For every year that you delay your OAS pension, your pension increases by 7.2%. At age 70, your monthly amount will be 36% higher than at age 65. If you delay, think about how you’ll support yourself while waiting for your higher OAS pension. After age 70, there is no advantage in delaying your first payment. In fact, you risk losing payments.

auto-increase.p1: (FR) Whenever you chose to start your OAS pension, it will automatically increase by 10% when you turn 75.
auto-increase.p2: (FR) If you choose to delay and collect a higher pension, the 10% automatic increase at age 75 will give you more money.

we-pay.heading: (FR) We pay OAS automatically for many, but some clients still need to apply
we-pay.p: (FR) In some cases, Service Canada will automatically enrol you to start your Old Age Security (OAS) pension at age 65. The month after turning 64 years old, you may receive a letter from Service Canada. The letter will say that you could be eligible for the OAS pension and have been selected for automatic enrolment. If this letter comes to you and you want to start your OAS pension later, you will need to let Service Canada know. Steps on how to delay your pension will be on your letter. There's no automatic enrolment into the OAS pension at age 70.

high-income.heading: (FR) If you have high income in retirement
high-income.p: (FR) If your annual income is over a certain amount after age 65, you must repay part or all your OAS pension. This is called the <a1>Old Age Security (OAS) pension recovery tax</a1>.

cpp-pension.heading: (FR) CPP retirement pension
cpp-pension.p1: (FR) No matter how often you changed jobs, by working in Canada, you contributed to the Canada Pension Plan (CPP) or the <a1>Québec Pension Plan (QPP)</a1>. The amount of your CPP retirement pension depends on how much and for how long you have contributed to the plan. The CPP lets you choose when to start your retirement pension, and each month you delay increases your monthly amount. The highest monthly amount you can receive happens at age 70, after which there is no benefit to waiting. If you need money sooner, you can start collecting your pension as early as age 60, but with a permanent reduction.
cpp-pension.p2: (FR) Your CPP retirement pension could more than double if started at age 70, instead of 60. The chart is an illustration of the pension increase with age and uses an illustrative pension amount.
cpp-pension.p3: (FR) Read <a2>Fred decides when to start his public pensions</a2> to see what guides his choices.
cpp-pension.smart-tip: (FR) Smart tip: The average Canadian who takes their pension at age 60, might be losing $100,000 in retirement income. Every month you delay your pension, increases your monthly payment. If you delay your CPP retirement pension from age 60 to 70, you could more than double your monthly amount. Your pension will change to reflect future inflation.
cpp-pension.disclaimer: (FR) Disclaimer: This website is meant to give you tips on when to take your public pensions. We do not provide financial advice. Once you have all the information you need, we encourage you to seek help from a financial advisor.
